citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The program of veterinary care has not been updated to include birds. A program of veterinary care is required to ensure
facilities are communicating with and following recommendations from their veterinarian. Each dealer and exhibitor shall
employ an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time attending veterinarian or
consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care that includes all
regulated animals and regularly scheduled visits to the premises.
Correct by: Feb 1, 2024

Approximately 5 pot-bellied pigs were housed in an enclosure with excessive mud. The pigs had minimal dry area to
escape from the mud. Prolonged exposure to wet, muddy conditions could predispose the pigs to foot and health
problems. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water and allow the pigs to escape the mud if
they choose.
Correct by: Jan 22, 2024

The coati’s enclosure had an accumulation of old food and feces on the bottom of the enclosure. Old food can become
spoiled and cause illness in the animals. Old food and feces can attract flies and pests which could cause stress and/or
illness in the animals.
Enclosures shall be cleaned as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to
minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.
Correct by: Jan 22, 2024

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not have a plan for environmental enhancement for the birds. Birds are extremely intelligent animals and
require mental stimulation for their health and well-being. Dealers, exhibitors and research facilities must develop,
document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological
well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the
regulations and with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference
guides.
Correct by: Feb 1, 2024

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The large macaw enclosure had an accumulation of old food and feces on the ground. Old food can become spoiled and
cause illness in the animals. Old food and feces can attract flies and pests which could cause stress and/or illness in the
animals.
Excreta and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures and from under and around primary enclosures as
often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and food waste.
Correct by: Jan 22, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The program of veterinary care has not been updated to include birds. A program of veterinary care is required to ensure 
facilities are communicating with and following recommendations from their veterinarian.  Each dealer and exhibitor shall 
employ an attending veterinarian  under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time attending veterinarian  or 
consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care that includes all 
regulated animals and regularly scheduled visits to the premises. 
Correct by: Feb 1, 2024 
3.127(c) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Approximately 5 pot-bellied pigs were housed in an enclosure with excessive mud. The pigs had minimal dry area to 
escape from the mud. Prolonged exposure to wet, muddy conditions could predispose the pigs to foot and health 
problems. A suitable method shall be provided  to rapidly eliminate excess water and allow the pigs to escape the mud if 
they choose.  
Correct by: Jan 22, 2024 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
The coati’s enclosure had an accumulation of old food and feces on the bottom of the enclosure. Old food can become 
spoiled and cause illness in the animals. Old food and feces can attract flies and pests which could cause stress and/or 
illness in the animals. 
Enclosures shall be cleaned as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to 
minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.  
Correct by: Jan 22, 2024 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.

The facility does not have a plan for environmental  enhancement for the birds. Birds are extremely intelligent animals and 
require mental stimulation for their health and well-being. Dealers, exhibitors and research facilities must develop, 
document, and follow a species-appropriate  plan for environment  enhancement adequate to promote the psychological 
well-being of birds. The plan must be approved  by the attending veterinarian  and must be in accordance with the 
regulations and with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference 
guides.  
Correct by: Feb 1, 2024 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The large macaw enclosure had an accumulation of old food and feces on the ground. Old food can become spoiled and 
cause illness in the animals. Old food and feces can attract flies and pests which could cause stress and/or illness in the 
animals. 
Excreta and food waste must be removed  from primary enclosures and from under and around primary enclosures as 
often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and food waste. 
Correct by: Jan 22, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
